newsitem.title: CANADA: Bre-X chief clarifies Busang rights.
newsitem.headline: Bre-X chief clarifies Busang rights.

text.p: Bre-X Minerals Ltd owns its 45 stake in the huge Indonesian gold deposit, Busang, through a wholly-owned Dutch subsidiary, chief executive officer David Walsh told Reuters on Friday.

Because of this corporate structure, Bre-X does not need to offer its Indonesian partners in Busang the right of first refusal if Bre-X decides to sell its Dutch subsidiary, Walsh said in a telephone interview.
"Bre-X's 45 percent shareholding is owned by a wholly owned Dutch subsidiary of Bre-X," Walsh said. "Bre-X has the right to sell any or all of that Dutch subsidiary without prior notice to anybody."
"We can do whatever we want with that," he added.

Walsh was responding to comments by Muhammad "Bob" Hasan, who told the Toronto Globe and Mail on Friday that Bre-X must give first rights of refusal to its partners in the joint venture company that will own the huge Busang gold mine.
Hasan owns controlling stakes in two Indonesian companies in the joint venture.
"Let's just get this clear," said Walsh. "Mr. Hasan is correct in that at the joint-venture company level, any owner has to offer rights of first refusal to the other partners."
But the rule does not apply to selling off the subsidiary, Walsh said.

Walsh also said that an arrangement with Sigit Harjojudanto, the son of Indonesian President Suharto, had expired. Last year, Bre-X set up an alliance with Sigit which would have given him a 10 percent stake in Busang as well as US$40 million over 40 months.
"That agreement expired without compensation," Walsh said on Friday.
He reiterated that Bre-X has always had clear title to the Busang site and that none of the company's directors or managers has been involved in "any impropriety."
Walsh said he will make a public announcement on Monday outlining Bre-X's history with Busang.
